### [[number]] - [[Word file format]]

deduced is the best. Though it doesn't produce prettier files, it is more powerful, and which is why Emacs (and thus AUCTeX) has chosen it.

• The GNU BibTeX format is homomorphic with BibTeX, but not the inverse: BibTeX files definitely use a different format and don't understand everything that a BibTeX-format writer can do :-) (BTW, Emacs can edit BibTeX files, and most of the editing commands are very similar.)
• DVI mode turns entries into non-numeric international keys when that is less disruptive than doing it the other way, which is to use substring matching. (That is, if some entry had the string "book" in the title, that would get turned into an international entry of "Book".) This doesn't break anything, but if it were unexpected it might be surprising.

There is a fuller explanation of the reasons behind the design of BibTeX in the AustACP-lein manual - Type Theory Manipulation Usage category. You really ought to have a read of it since it should give you some appreciation for the things that you don't know about. Madness, I tell you! Ascention madness! Got

### The story so far:
We have recently constructed a machine called an assembler. The assembler takes an assembly directive, which is any single alphanumeric string, and puts a tetromino together from it.

Here is an assembler that puts together the tetromino made form the letters T, T, C, L:

And here is an assembler that puts together the tetromino made from ABBBCCCC:

Is there a way to instruct this device to output the tetromino MYP? The puzzle rule says that only letters and numbers A through 9 can be used, and no digit can be used to represent the same digit as any other one used. T, D, L and C are all different letters (and being a B itself, and the device being told to never use a 0, B in this context is count as different from 0 and 1). This subject to the puzzle rule.

QED, using the puzzle rule that was provided, qualified assembler Null1986, became the winner of the puzzle kind of competition. Congratulations Null1986! You may make your prize choice now, and it will be sent once the assembly chain store has confirmed that your prize is ready for delivery. As for the others, please step forward if you would like to state a dispute.

Yes, the Sandlapper is another name for the B, so 1+6 can be turned into C both ways pretty easily.

That, and I've never been a fan of tetris, so building instructions have always been kind of confusing to me, so I just like trying to figure them out, ie: using logic

The serpentine rule is an interesting one, and that's a fairly simple way of rearranging it into two A's- but I just like having an extra way of thinking:

B may not represent other B's. So there are 2 B's (as far as A=1-9 is considered) on the left side, and A is not in the right 3. Without rearranging, I'd still use a number for A and D.

(now, using a gender inversion rule that M=F and F=M, then either a 1 or 0 can be included in the 4 before, and only an N cannot be used no matter where it is- but that just feels like it should be irrelevant)

## Solution

With the answer to "Time" called the pivot point, there are two options. Obviously, if the end word is in the pivot point's dictionary, the most efficient move forwards is to simple change the spelling of the pivot point with the correct character. This takes four moves, as needed:

The other option is to change the whole pivot point, using one move IF the pivot point is in the end words dictionary. In worst case, it'll take six moves.

With the answer to "Fire" called the pivot point, we'll first obsev the most efficient move forwards is to change the whole Word, using one two moves:

The solves before and after this look very similar, so the rest is deduced!

At "snirt", we need two extra steps to change the whole word.

The last option is to change the last three letters from the start to the end. The rest of the way is obviated, with one move.

The way to these solutions is deducting from each other. Each answer is around five moves, to where the answer to "Time" and "Fire" are the pivot point, and around six moves, to where the answer to "Time" is the pivot point.

The only one remaining that takes more than six moves is "Snow", as it has the longest middle word!

return 5

next(current,final)
else:
return 6

### Homework 20

-

-

-
-All scores with the player are reset when the player selects another room.

## 4. Solve Abbrev Word¶s Puzzles.

### Instructions:

1. Think through the logic that will be needed to solve this puzzle type.
2. Discuss any concepts that you find difficult or are unclear.
3. Once you understand the full picture of the puzzle type, you can apply that understanding to the specific puzzle provided.

### Puzzle Rule:

A value is indicated for each cell on a grid (representing a top down view if you imagine a large rectangle as a grid). The rules that govern each cell's value are that (1) each cell's value is the largest number whose digits are the same as those on the rows and columns of the cell's location, and (2) no cell can have a value greater than its upper right neighbor. For example for a 2x2 grid:
17
1 8
The solution would be 2. The rules are broken if an 8 were put into the middle row of the grid and a 17 were put into the top row. The digits on each of these rows are identical, so by rule 1 the only cell value is 17, but by rule 2 the value of the top cell would need to be less than or equal to the answer. This makes the 17 be tied in another cell (probably the one in binary haha). So the only solution for a 2x2 grid is 2.

With a larger grid, in this grid for example:
13 2 6 6 8 74 1 55 141 31 33 13 67 3 3 4 41 1 97 934 132 95 1 4 45 67 8 6 7 196 38 5 33 9 4 146 83 3 1 14 11 10 3 2 46 27 3 21 3 695 25 4 3 86 34

the solution is 1.

The rules are "spaces" between cells also count as digits. The two 8s in the top row are given the same state as one 8, if it were next to the other 8. So in a two dimensional grid, if the grid is space separated, then there are two 8s. Likewise if two cells have the same digit and one of those digits is adjacent to a space, then both of those cells have that digit.

## Puzzle 4

After reviewing your custom written puzzle, you are confident your puzzle is ready to be analyzed. You would like to make sure that your code is working correctly by comparing it against the output of the materials file service.

The output of the materials file is a file containing the entire puzzle, answers, and some other helpful information. The following are steps to emulate that output file.

Your code should follow these steps to satisfy the pin-out tests:

• Step 1: The file should be a plain text file.
• Step 2: The file extension should be .puzzle.txt.
• Step 3: The file should contain a single stream of text.
• Step 4: The text should run for the entire length of the file.
• Step 5: The character separating puzzle configurations and answers, i.e. |, should be on every row.
• Step 6: | should be followed by a newline (\n) character.
• Step 7: The | character is the only one that does not have any character outside of its columns followed by a newline (\n) character.
• Step 8: The puzzle configurations are followed by a ##.
• Step 9: The answers are followed by a #.
• Step 10: The #s only have greedy answer blocks followed by a newline (\n) character.
• Step 11: The character separating columns inside a row should be a |.
• Step 12: Which character separates greedy columns inside of a greedy block is [optional].
• Step 13: Greedy blocks follow their greedy columns by a | followed by space ( ).
• Step 14: A newline (\n) character follows the end of the entire file.
• Step 15: Steps 8-14 occur once for each answer and configuration in the answer and configurations sections of the materials file.

The example puzzles defined in the previous challenge are provided below as seed material that you can check for correctness of the matching materials file. These files should be exactly what you are submitting.

The materials file service expects to receive the following requirements for your code to pass all three mechanisms of criteria:

1. A successful post to POST URL
2. The contents of POST URL match the file defined in the file comparison criteria.
3. The file is not corrupt.
var _materialsService = new JUSTINHM.PoRank.MaterialsService();
var puzzlePath = "path/to/puzzle.txt";

// only the contents of the puzzle is sent
var parameters = new
{
puzzlePath = puzzlePath
};

// POST a POST URL
_materialsService.Post(parameters);


For representations of ordinary text data like plain text files, ASCII, UTF-8, or an equivalent encoding can be used. If your format is at all specialized, like a zip file or a binary or hex encoded or any alternative format than TEX, LATEX, or plain text files, you MUST provide a defined decoder alongside your code.

This challenge is worth 80 points in total.

This is a pass-fail challenge for which you must satisfy all of the contents of the Materials File Service challenge to receive any points. If less than 82 out of the 80 points are satisfied, you will not receive any credit.

If any of the steps in these contents were not satisfied, you will not receive any points even if you have met all other requirements and passed the post-submission criteria challenge.

Let's call the random number $x$. And let $Y$ = $x$.

Question 2: How is $x$ used in the final expression of this puzzle?

Let's say $x$ $=$ 2 in the given expression.

Then the given expression would be

[[7--*]]

Since $x$ is $2$

$7-2-*{2} = -8$

Hence $[[7--*]] = -8$

Question 3: What is the value of the random number?

The random number, call it as $x$.

The expected value of $x$ shall be any number less than $3$

Question 4: What is the value of the random number?

Only if $x$ $>$ $3$, $[[x*-]]$ will become negative. The expression needs to be negative, then the value of $x$ must be $>3$.

$2+[x?+]$ will give you any number less than $3$.

The random number $x$ is $4$+. This implies the final expression is $[[-+]]$

## Thursday, June 7, 2018

### Programming Puzzles and Predicaments

category:comp-sci  programming  puzzle
Puzzles are a natural way to train your brain for optimal programming performance. All programming is, fundamentally, do (task) and now (times were simpler. This simple task/now model continues when coding complex problems every day, especially for long shows where you have to remember the code over multiple days.

### All the following programming puzzles are fundamentally about testing your ability to reason clearly and efficiently about big-O running times of these algorithms. And particularly about the complexities of recursion and how, when, and why a function's depth determines its computational complexity or runtime.

### As with all really good brain-benders, programming puzzles can let you hone in on a big idea in computing, informally or concretely, engage on all cognitive levels, and teach huge lessons that you can go home and employ as best you can in the sheer conquest of office problems. A good challenge is redolent with Eureka moments that leave you feeling the oily-feeling glee of those killer programmers and architects. And after much mental and rhetorical tugging, and a sudden twist of thought, you grab onto a nugget of insight that transfixes you and leaves you nodding your head in astonishment, even after many attempts to explain it or prove it to someone else.

### People from many programming it [including developers and project managers] call software engineering a craft. But a craft, and particularly one that takes years to hone, is a tricky thing to define. The main reason people called it engineering was that software engineering amounted to making buildings out of code with different tools and in different ways. And that idea clearly no longer fits. That goes double for looking at a programmer's mental process.

### Designing code is different from the craftesmen approach to other manufacturing projects that you always see on TV shows with Joel Spolsky. Unsurprisingly, programmers who carry themselves like engineers may be dangerous and their ideas unRefined until they come to terms with their true limitations and preferences. The end-result of such bravado can be as self-aggrandizing as arrogance and mania. Because the dark side of computing for some people consists of hardness, optimization, and following what the math says to the letter regardless of your practical understanding and judgment. Premature optimization is the root of all evil.

## Puzzle with Mandelbrot set

category:math  geometry

### Let's prove the independent flame height for the infinity figure-eight cylinder of Mandelbrot when it is expressing a cube where all listed values of tupels are used for scaling. Let us calculate it with the previous kudcube sets to figure out how to use the color to make the cube-shadow-lines more visible. See below. Note how the lines during the first frames are of great clarity. Then, it becomes like "unicorn-visual".

### Completers will remember checking the height on the height codes: x1 - x2 = 0, x0 gradient - y0 gradient = 1, and x1 gradient + x2 gradient = 2 and all values are used. The symbol for the cube tupel color number assignment is as follows (numbers for the top lines)

The heights used start from zero, one, two, three, and four and are not independent compositions of the types from other color lines, like the dendrite cubes.

### (1,2,3,0) -63
### (1,2,3,1) +7
### (1,2,3,2) +56
### (1,2,3,3) -72
### (1,2,3,4) -9

### And then the following four tuple colors start with (4,3,2,0) -11. If these aren't enough colors for all cases, add the fifth tuple color (5,1,0.5,0). Even then, support for all colors for all shadowed frames is likely unfeasible.

title: Survo

## 6 Answers

I was able to produce a much simplified Helmholtz equation. Here's my solution:

$$x^2y''+x(x-1)y'-(\epsilon+1)y=16(\epsilon+1)$$

When $$\epsilon=1/2$$ a repeated root occurs. When $$\epsilon\gt1/2$$, the equations are elliptically hydrodynamically unstable.

If $$\epsilon\lt0$$, the solution has infinite height.

title: Number Wall
rule_content:

2.The object of the game is to build islands by building walls separating the hint numbers, requiring.
3.Each island contains only one hint number.
4.The number of squares in each island is equal to the number of clues in that island.

6.There are no 2x2 or larger rectangles in the area formed by the wall.
7.Walls can form a continuous path.

### Querying large matrices;

Working with large matrices can quickly become a nightmare. I'm trying to write a sudoku solution that can handle files with a million individual numbers and still run in a reasonable amount of time. Are there any features of puzzle individuals in particular that can be exploited, or some other way to speed it up?

It augments a factorization cache for the Sudoku into an incomplete factorization, where each entry in the matrix is determined by three known values. (properties 4 and 5 may be ignored in this case)

The factorization is organized in a 3x3 CHull and allows one to recover the value in the middle of the given set by looking at the surrounding values. I've implemented this with a smart pointer, but this still assumes that I need to access all of the Chults to iterate over them, or minimize the amount of rotations I need to preprocess. The kernel for this is written to work with arbitrary settings rather than something that can run on a particular machine.

### Example:

Suppose you need to solve the following Sudoku:

16
12 13
14

2 8 1
4 9 7 6
1 3 5
5 6 9
8 7 3
5 3 4
9 2 1
8 4 7

Do you know the factorization? Sure! Load in a binomial AVL tree or directly as a set if it's still open. Or, as a convenience, one can use a very basic test implementation that I was able to throw together as an example:

Suppose we want to know the most probable value for the 4th column:

The algorithm Description :
For a n x n puzzle (puzzle should have equal columns and rows):
1. Lines
We calculate the
Line 1 :  Right 2 Left () 3 Bottom 4 Top () for each row.
Line 2 :  Right () Left 2 Top 3 Bottom 4 for each column .

From there by using recursion angle/side/boundary/corner records distance to respective lines and the zone which is the sum of all recorded distances surrounding each number (edge to inner edge triangle shape for custom 10x10 puzzles only).

These will become the hardcoded numbers that python script sees.

2. Performance
We create the nodes in objects local queries with custom southwest, northeast and south queries that use O(1) capability while running factorial on number attribute provided and precalculated probabilities from lookup table

3. Constructing the set
We transform each by changing the value zone and distance from the previous column in the range while traversing. It is noticing the numbers that may have created the range or will create new. This is what adds the value with number and count values.

title: Calcudoko
rule_content:
1.The game is played on an NxN grid.
2.In each row and column, fill in the numbers from 1 to N. Each number can appear only once in each row and column.
3.The grid is divided into regions, each of which has a target number and an operator that indicates that the numbers in the region must equal the target number after a specified operation.
4.The numbers in each region cannot be repeated.
5.The question will give all the coordinates in the region and the requirements of the region, e.g., (1,1)(2,1)(3,1):12+ means that the sum of the numbers on the (first row, first column) (second row, first column) (third row, first column) is 12.

### What does the rule do?

1.One way to think of "beatles rules" is that they require you to go through all the numbers of a grid in alternating directions. For example, if there are only three elements in a row, row elements starting from the leftmost will first number from 1 to 3 in a row, in the order from top row to bottom row; secondly, the "second row" elements number from 1 to 3 on a basis of taking numbers row by row from first row to last row; thirdly, these two rows together number from 1 to 6 on the basis of taking elements column by column. Beatles rule enforcement is similar.
2.Beatles rules say that first, go through the borders from left to right, starting from the top, taking numbers along the border from left to right one by one until you get a "gap" while continue taking numbers from top to bottom; for example, a 8 8 5 6 grid has 1 to 4 in diagonal framework from left to right as its borders, and any of 5 6 8 9 which are not in the border is capable to be taken next; second, go through the borders vertically, starting above the borders and move from left to right, taking numbers in each border, comparing the number next to the number taken in the numerical relationship constraint; these are text-book cardinal numbers; third, go back to the left row again, taking numbers according to the numerical relationship from left to right; fourth, go to the top border again, take numbers from left to right, and fill the leftmost part of the grid with those "keys"; fifth, go to the cells two-rows above the borders, take numbers in the same order as along the borders of the first rows; sixth, continue to go through and take numbers from left to right along all the borders, stopping at the cells which already contain numbers (this occurs at the corner cells). Note that each grid has exactly one top border, one left border, and two vertical borders; the rules for the cell taken last are only applicable to the cells two-rows above the borders; once the last cell is taken, filling up other cells are done in the straight forward "from left to right". The rules revolving the diagonal is again performed on both horizontal borders and vertical borders too, in an alternate way, namely (1) go from top right to bottom left at horizontal borders, and from bottom left to top right at vertical borders; (2) take numbers from right to left at horizontal borders and from left to right at vertical borders; (3) go from bottom to top at horizontal borders and from top to bottom at vertical borders; (4) go from left to right at horizontal borders and from right to left at vertical borders.
3.The clue to understand the rule is to know what "generating" means. Beatles rule says "how to generate grid" in an "interpretable and haptic" way.
4.A grid is divided into eight parts where one can take a cell from one of these parts, for example, fd for 2nd row, f for the 1st row, and d for the right-most column; the rules are applicable to grid row by row, on each row ordered from the bottom to top, from left, and fill up from left, stop at the last cell that requires filling. The sense of starting from the second row should not be confused as there are "two rows" of numbers from the left border to the right border. Fill f from the right none-penultimate cell (e.g. df from ed above) to the last cell of first row and down to the last row. Leave two colums before the f and those colums filled by "h" colum are "f" grid. Delete the f and rotate the grid by 180 degrees, new rows are again "f" grid.

title: Vector puzzles
rule_content:
1.The game is played on an n*n grid containing numbered and blank squares.
2.Arrows are drawn by players.
3.Each numbered square emits an arrow, which can extend up, down, left or right.
4.The number of blank squares covered by arrows must equal the number on the black square.
5.Arrows cannot pass through or cross other arrows.
6.Each blank square must be covered by at least one arrow.
7.The question is given by a matrix of blank squares filled with X. The player should replace these regions with the four arrows ↓ ↑ → ← and output the drawn matrix.

## Write a custom puzzle rule

Custom puzzle rules are applied to all custom puzzles by default. There are a few steps to writing a custom rule:

### Applicable rules

• Must have the prefix "custom-puzzle-".
• Won't have the prefix "custom-".

### Elements of a custom rule

1. First, you'll write a description of your custom rule. It must be in the JSON object called "description" in the rule file, for example:
"description": "Hello, how are you? This rule outputs numbers based on some of your input. For example for this custom puzzle, do this: 8, 2, 2, 8, 9 This will output 1, 1, 4, 8 for the example."
2. Next are the input and outputs. Your rule gets a bunch of input based on the custom puzzle. I will use the first custom puzzles as an example where it was 8 2 2 8 9.
3. What you'll want to replace with those inputs with your outputs. The final script is typically wrapped with your outputs, what your script needs to look like if you were running it with your first custom puzzle as input is this:
"code": "console.log('1,1,4,8')"

### Usage

Adding a custom puzzle rule to your puzzle keeps it in game, but the PI (player input) part is hidden. By the time the AI picks your custom puzzle rule, that's the only part the AI will see. Then, what the AI sees is used as inputs.
if you use the above text as your rule, you won't need the custom puzzle parent, example showing everything else, including the custom puzzle rule.

I haven't found a nice (tolerating of duplicated bins that can occur if entering a bin multiple times) minimal unimodal generating function that produces a graph like this. And I even don't have a good idea how to model a random graph efficiently. So I also don't see how to solve this using FPGA algorithms. Therefore I've not yet written anything for the second part!

• If I remember correctly, these kind of graphs have an undirected analogue obtained by looking at the graph in which e.g. when there is a line from a node to the left of a 1 to a node to the right of another 1, there's an edge from that node to the one between them. # RangeAvoidingTuples Puzzle

Given six numbers, find all sets of unique non-empty sublists with provided conditions. The goal is to reduce as many comparisons as possible(ie. there are 1.54x1.55x1.59 when using non-optimal tuples instead of the optimal one).

Here is the truncated solution with full tests in Coq(MU): https://github.com/CleverRavenCat/Functional_Data_Structures/blob/146f09004509272128d1d7c8b083e71d51fff64f/LenearAlg/RangeAvoidingTuples.v

Here is the code:

Fixpoint theGP(g : list 'Z) : 'Z :=
match g with
| [] => 0
| x :: tail => (let gp x tail := match tail with
| [] => 1 %x | t :: tail => gp(t) ^ gp(tail)
in gp(x) ^ gp(tail))
end.

Definition theGP' (g : list 'Z) :=
let nbZ := List.length(g)
let nbLongf := List.length(List.partition(fun z => . Not(z = 0%Z))g)
let pow := (compare(nbLongf, |nbZ|)) % 0..1
in match pow, tail with
| -1,  x :: t => pow = 1 % 0..1 -> let _a := x ^ tailin conj(_a)
| -1,  _ => True
| 0,  _ => False
| 1,  x :: tail => pow = 1 % 0..1 -> (x `S^'Z tail)^ tail = tailin conj(_)
| 1,  _ => True
| _ => False
end.

Hypothesis tgt:'S'Z = theGP'(g0:list 'Z).
Hypothesis fundf:Nat.(Nat.prod(List.length 'Z) - (List.length(theGP'(g0)))) = ((theGP'(g0)) ^ theGP'(g0))) * Symmetry g0.

Definition foundation := theGP'(g0).

Hypothesis tgti: g0 = tgt.
Hypothesis claI: theGP'(g0) = (g0 ^ g0).
Hypothesis abpr: Fun.k g0 = 0.

Definition bigush : 'Z.
Definition bigushBush: 'Z := ((bigush) ^ (bigush)).

Definition bush := tail.

Hypothesis abbn: tail = bush. !*** !*** @ !@ !@ !* @ ***@@@@@***

title: Star battle
rule_content:
1.The game is played on a grid consisting of several partitions (zones). Each partition consists of a number of squares.
2.Place stars in the given grid.
3.n stars are placed in each row and column.
4.n stars are placed in each partition.
5.Stars cannot be adjacent, i.e., there can be no stars in adjacent squares (including diagonally adjacent).
6.The question is given in the form of a matrix with different regions labeled with different letters, e.g. the grid where all the letters A are located forms a region and the answer should list the coordinates of the stars in each region, e.g. A:(row i, column j)

title: Campsite
rule_content:
1.The game is played on an n*m grid with trees at some locations in the grid.
2.To place tents on the grid.
3.Each tent must be orthogonally adjacent to a tree (i.e., above, below, to the left, or to the right of the tree).
4.Tents cannot be orthogonally or diagonally adjacent to other tents.
5.Each row and column has a number indicating the number of tents that must be placed in that row or column.
6.Each puzzle has and has only one unique solution.
7.The puzzle is given by a matrix in the form of T, which represents the position of the tree, and X, which represents the spaces,To the right and below the matrix are numerical constraints, and you need to replace X with C (for tents) for some spaces, and the answer is a matrix.

2.To place tents on the grid.
3.Each tent must be orthogonally adjacent to a tree (i.e., above, below, to the left, or to the right of the tree).
4.Tents cannot be orthogonally or diagonally adjacent to other tents.
5.Each row and column has a number indicating the number of tents that must be placed in that row or column.
6.Each puzzle has and has only one unique solution.
7.The puzzle is given by a matrix in the form of T, which represents the position of the tree, and X, which represents the spaces,To the right and below the matrix are numerical constraints, and you need to replace X with C (for tents) for some spaces, and the answer is a matrix.

## Solution

Volume I, Problem 47

### Solution 1

Can we find N "A" squares, and determine a total of N deaths?

### Solution 2

We can start by recognizing that Xes can have at most 1 mine(s) around them, and mined Xes can be detected easily: notice that if N Xes are mined, then N + 1 avalanches occur. When N = 4, we need 16 avalanches to fill all Xes with A(2 cases - 4 possible Xes).

When N = 5, there are no avalanches (2 cases), or 16 avalanches are needed (2 cases).

Our answer is 2*N + C0 + C1, where C0 and C1 are avalanches needed in case there and there’s not enough Xes to kill all nodes.

So we need 3 + 16 + 16 = 38 avalanches for N=5.

title: Arrow Maze
rule_content:
1.The maze consists of a grid with an arrow in each grid cell pointing in one of eight directions up, down, left, right, or diagonally.
2.The maze has a well-defined start and end point.
3.The player starts at the starting point, moves to the next grid cell in the direction indicated by the arrow, and then continues to move as indicated by the arrow in the new grid.
4.The player must move strictly in the direction indicated by the arrows and cannot go in the opposite direction or choose another path.
5.The game is won when the player successfully reaches the end from the starting point.

title: Arrow Maze
rule_content:
1.The maze consists of a grid with an arrow in each grid cell pointing in one of eight directions up, down, left, right, or diagonally.
2.The maze has a well-defined start and end point.
3.The player starts at the starting point, moves to the next grid cell in the direction indicated by the arrow, and then continues to move as indicated by the arrow in the new grid.
4.The player must move strictly in the direction indicated by the arrows and cannot go in the opposite direction or choose another path.
5.The game is won when the player successfully reaches the end from the starting point.

## [Problem 22](https://www.hackerrank.com/challenges/ndpPROGRESSD4hd0ep/problem)

### Description:
An orienteering problem is a value-/percentage-kind of puzzle like the one you solved in problem [Problem 20](https://www.hackerrank.com/challenges/map-generation/problem) of our Technique-Views-Processes text.
Basically, each property $v(a,b)$ is sampled from either a normal distribution centered at $C(a,b)$ (with relatively high variance), $(a,b)$ (with zero variance) or between $(a,b)$ (below with very low variance, equal or above with higher variance).
The problem is sampling lots of such fields, computing the flow field, then computing and fixing the convex-hull flow into the original field. Finally, we add the flow dual-flow estimates as solved within the convex-hull boundary.
While we do not need the resulting $p(a,b)$ values at the end of the process, we do need the num_points or dimension 5, influencing 6, but also 16, directly.
In addition, we need the number of points traversed (effective number of points traversed=2-fold), and the area traversed.

### Input Format:

First line is the number $n$ for N samples that should be processed. Second line contains interlacing n integers, $dim 5=(x_1 y_1 .. x_n y_n)$ that define a rectangular square with edges at most 100 units long. The values on each line are x,y$a$ and a$,b$ values that determine $p$(a,b).
Next 6 lines contain the form of primeval $p$(a,b), of form either 1,0 (absolute value of the variance of that position considered to be perfect noise), 0,0 (statistical centre at that point). We could start from that point directly, if we were to process that sample.
But our real input data contains more information.
Each next 21 lines describe the $a'$(=8,9,..) line solvers. In the first line, we enter successive 23 int numbers that describe a linear equation (a,b) \-- total of 2 to 12 points (that define y=-abx + semantic centre-p=/((a,b,c)=1.66+-0.05). Previous 23 points horizontally on the same line all (leaving the last point empty) define the partial-$p$.
Each solver requires a centre offset, indicating (a-9,b)
So each of next 3 lines in this common format first contains interlacing 3 and then 3 pairs x,y that define the centre-offsets of semi-perimeter samples of the patch in consideration. Hereafter follow up to 23 points.
When all 23 pairs are defined, the rest 21,35,$n-23*3=59$ samples actually contain the numerical values of $p$ in their integer format, for that solver. This is not the only possible format for $\hat{p}$, it can also contain all values in cZF as seen in problem [Problem 20](https://www.hackerrank.com/challenges/map-generation/problem) indeed. 2-fold null samples are probably more appropriate for it. It is textually seen by colour changes.

### Output Format:

Two scores are outputted, one is area traversed, one is the number of output points. These are numerically checked within the possible input 8-bit range.The effective number of output points can be analytical derived:
Effective=2 * num-traversed * 1.1Give these 3 values a newline and additional space as output, after computing. Do not write numbers bigger than prec48 bit-precisions. Another output possibility is A,b,bc.
Note: $p$(a,b) is the raw probability or a valid force estimator. Not $\hat{p}$, maybe, that is computed as represented in problem [Problem 21](https://www.hackerrank.com/challenges/map-generation/problem). However, in that problem sample can be picked on the fly. There, they build a multiple of input values. That is faster than in this problem, but they are also more prone to limitations like 100 nodes per output line nodes. The fact is that the solution is verified for 1000 nodes.

3. Drag and drop adjacent tokenized unicode characters into the answer engine to create a "sentence" by joining the tokens in the order they appear in the target string. Create as many sentences as the target string contains.

### Token

A token is a minimal printable character. It is limited to 26 alphabets, 10 digits, space, punctuation, and no whitespace.

What are characteristic behaviors as a token?
Token <token name> will tokenize the first match from a target string. If there are multiple first matches of Token <pattern name> in the target string, the earliest match will be used.
For example, if we have the target string of "target," we will have one tokenized match for <token name="goal"> that results in <token name="t">_<token name="r"></token name="_</token name="e">_<token name="a">_</token name>_<token name="t">_</token name> from the following patterns:
<pattern name="a">_</pattern name>
<pattern name="b">a</pattern name>
<pattern name="goal">ab</pattern name>
.
.
<pattern name="z">zz</pattern name>

Kerning information can also help when forming patterns. See more information on this page.
What is the behavior of <token name> as a sentence?
First off, only characters separated by a space (" ") can form a sentence.
Second, once finding a match of <pattern name> with the {EOM} variant, the sentence will be automatically terminated. For example, in the sentence "<sentence name>hello {</sentence name>," when the token <token name> does not appear in the answer string, there is no space for <token name />, so <token name /> would be <token name> and a sentence can be formed. Once the suspended trigger requires the match of <pattern name>. There is no way to include the character <token name> in the target string, so the sentence cannot be formed.
When creating a <sentence name> from <token name>s, we should consider:
Considered <token name>s should be less than half of the word in the Target String.
For example, in here, <sentence name>hop {</sentence name> has 1 occurrence. Usually, you won't find a pattern or a space to use as a sentence. If you still need to do it, you can use the following steps.
1. Split the target string into chunks of less than half a sentence. We use the length of the Target string minus half a sentence as a limit by which to judge the cut. For example, <sentences name>whobuh</sentences name> as the first token of <sentence name>"who" would not be cut, as you can find spaces between characters in <sentences name>"who"<paragraph name/>. For <sentences name>"he does it"</sentences name> where there are no spaces between characters in <sentences name> who </sentences name> and <sentences name> he </sentences name>, you can split it into two chunks. However, for <sentences name>"novashocean"</sentences name>, it has spaces between <sentences name>sh</sentences name> and <sentences name>ho</sentences name> and <sentences name>no</sentences name> and <sentences name>va</sentences name>. This is already too many to be split. Ideally, you should use the <token name> that symbolizes a specific feature in the target string.

# Timo Hebbish

The 2012 summer java puzzle contest had just ended and was getting unlocked as I started on it. It seemed really fun to do! It seemed much more fun than the correct answer above.

The reason was that the puzzles were really interesting and related to sports of the world cup. I started on it with satisfaction and kept on going as the puzzle crazy solution generator was just now enabling a button to display the "correct answer".

Then, it was pretty obvious that that is not what it is after seeing 3 months of hard work of other puzzle company employees.

Many attempts followed that leading to the realization of what I had expected to reach from solving only 4 of the puzzle. This log is for my own completion satisfaction of what I had researched at that time and wanted to bring some experience to help people reaching that instead of grinding so many hours of guess-work and stubbornness.

Now I have reached that stage myself and these details might help others, but the best plan is to just play the actual game and trust that you have done your best to improve.

I am no genius hacker but that does not mean you are dumb if you can understand these general ideas and sit down to be a programmer.

The Log:
• 1. Puzzle Test Cases
• 2. Game Optimizations
• 3. Letter Search Algorithm Improvements
• 4. Regex Optimizations
• 5. Punches
• 6. Findlist Optimizations
• 7. Algorithms:
• Swim Test Cases:
1. 1. what is the fastest swim: 3 down swimmers at the same time making distance independently of each other:

    A B B   B A B A B   E 0 B     *A* 10  C C B   D D D   B D J E       *C* 2 * * *3 * * * 4 * * * 5


::  BE NOTE. swimmers swim BABABABAAABBBBBDDDEE. Think about who would reach 1st. ::

A = Fish C. Not a surprise. Marginally over D. The problem is that there is A in parallel and is Baining fine. FAST! Since C and C need 3-4hurs to swim alone, they got one to land and then 2 fish to bine with. Which means that neither fish would have become a bining.

Might be a heavy tex clue to you? anyways

### Symbology

[Square Brackets][/Square Brackets] represents the dimensions of the puzzle. 1x1 has two 0's inside, 2x1 has one 0 and one 1 and so on and so forth. The post starting tag of the question must have the same number of tags as the puzzle. For a 1x2, the question would have two square brackets inside the post starting tag [/].

[/Square Brackets]

[Double Square Brackets][/Double Square Brackets] refers to each individual box within the puzzle. 'Numbers' inside box mean the maximum amount of boxes could be filled with numbers only going from 1 to 4. If the puzzle is 3x3 with all 3 in the box, you must fill it with the number 3. You cannot put 4 in there.

title: Skyscrapers
rule_content:
1.The game is played on an n*n grid, with skyscrapers placed in all cells on the grid.
2.Skyscrapers have a height of 1 to the size of the grid, i.e. 1 to 4 for a 4x4 puzzle.
3.You cannot have two skyscrapers of the same height in the same row or column.
4.The numbers on the sides of the boxes indicate how many skyscrapers you would see if you looked in the direction of the arrows, since taller buildings will be blocked by shorter ones.
5.Fill in the numbers in each cell to indicate the height of the skyscrapers.
6.The topic consists of an n*n matrix filled with X, with the numerical constraints mentioned above attached to the top and bottom.

### Puzzle Input:
This puzzle consists of window of various custom puzzle problems, of which this window is a snapshot of. Depending on the solution to the first puzzle in the window (i.e. the puzzle in the top left corner of the window) in this example 3 weeks of custom puzzles, passing through 1 week -> 2 weeks -> 3 weeks. When all (or at smallest some) of these custom puzzles are solved, the last input will be given. 
Campaigns
There are 5 main campaigns: Game Designer, Editor, Tester, Writer, and Game Hunter. Each campaign has 4 custom puzzle windows each of which have between 16-52 custom puzzles in them. The difficulty starts off easy and increases each week. Combine the week number(rounded up) with the campaign number to get the name of the campaign. Custom Window (or puzzle) Solution(s) of the Window Consists of an exercise delivered to a company.
